title.narrative: RWI Reg. Asia Progr. Human Rights and Sustainable Development 2017-2021
RWI Reg. Asien prog. Mänskliga rättigheter och hållbar utveckling 2017-2021

description.narrative:
Insatsen syftar till att bidra till implementeringen av regeringens strategi för regionalt utvecklingssamarbete i Asien och Oceaninen 2017-2021 som har som mål har som mål att bidra till ökad regional integration och samarbete för hållbar utveckling. Syftet med strategin är att stärka regionala aktörers förmåga att arbeta med gränsöverskridande utmaningar och möjligheter inom mänskliga rättigheter, demokrati, jämställdhet respektive miljö och klimat på ett ömsesidigt förstärkande sett.
Det föreslagna stödet till Raoul Wallenberg Institutets regionala program för mänskliga rättigheter och hållbar utveckling syftar till att bidra till en rättvis, inkluderande och hållbar utveckling i Asien genom att bidra till att stärka skyddet för mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet och miljö. Program som bygger på tre huvudkomponenter: 1. Att stärka kunskapen om samarbandet mellan mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet och miljö och tydligöra dessa samband och därigenom bidra till att påverka lagstiftning, policy och rättskipning i regionen. Det kommer ske genom forskning, utbildning och regionalt akademiskt utbyte. 2. Stärka synergier och samverkan mellan olika sektorer och aktörer i syfte att bygga broar mellan olika kunskapsområden som miljö och mänskliga rättigheter och därigenom bidra till en effektivare implementering av Agenda 2030. 3. Att bidra till att främja ökad tillgång till rättvisa för marginaliserade grupper i relation till miljö och mänskliga rättigheter för gränsöverskridande kränkningar begångna av icke-statliga aktörer.
Det första året planeras som ett pilot år där RWI planerar att starta upp verksamheten genom att påbörja forskning och utbildningsaktiviteter men också på att utveckla och formalisera sektorövergripande samarbeten. Under pilotåret ska RWI färdigställa ett konsoliderat program med budget för 2018-2021 och utveckla ett fullständigt resultatramverk och göra en fullständig riskbedömning och ta fram en plan för hur dessa risker ska hanteras. Sida ska godkänna dessa dokument innan ytterligare medel betalas ut.
Sida gör bedömningen att insatsen är relevant och att RWI och det planerade regionala programmet har goda förutsättningar att bidra till målen i den i ovan nämnda strategin.

RWI Regional Asia program on Human Rights and Sustanable Development 2017-2021 aims at strengthening the capacity and knowledge of regional and national actors. RWI has applied to Sida for 75 million SEK to carry out the "RWI Regional Asia programme on human rights and sustainable development 2017-2021". The intervention aims at: 1. Clarifying the linkages and application in the region and influencing policy and legal development through strengthening knowledge on the connections between human rights, gender equality and environment. Regional research, regional thematic studies and support to acadmic education in the field of human rights and environment will be the main activities here. 2. Strengthening multisector synergies, pursuing inclusive and rights-based action towards Agenda 2030 Exampls of activities are annual comprehensive blended learning courses, tailor-made courses to regional stakeholders from different sectors on human rights based approaches and linkages between human rights, gender equality, environment and sustainable development, as well as supporting regional, national and local multi-sectorial SDG processes with human rights indicators. 3. Promoting fair and efficient justice, including in relation to the environment and for cross-border human rights violations. This will be done through i.e. human rights capacity development for judges/judicial actors across the region, high-level NHRI meetings to further develop regional frameworks for addressing cross-boundary human rights protection issues, engagement with the ASEAN Intergovernmental Commission on Human Rights in key areas of the Commission's mandate, etc.

The intervention overarching intention is to contribute to a just, inclusive and sustainable development in Asia, through mutually reinforcing protection of human rights, gender equality and the environment. The resultsframwork was revised in late 2019 after a mid-term review was carried out. The overall problems that RWI has identified that the Regional Asia Program shall address are the following: 1. Lack of knowledge of linkages between human rights, gender equality and environment between and among actors, and lack of connected, qualitative and locally grounded, problem analyses required for such policies. 2. Insufficient collaboration and joint vision between different actors and sectors, which impedes synergies and efficiency in action which are preconditions for progress, including towards Agenda 2030 targets. 3. Gaps in accountability and access to justice on equal terms for all, including insufficient mechanisms for addressing extraterritorial and corporate harm. The Theory of Change for the programme is based on the assumption that addressing the problems mentioned above will achieve the overall objective of the programme to contribute to just, inclusive and sustainable development in the region through mutually reinforcing protection of human rights, gender equality and the environment. The intervention aims to strengthen knowledge regarding the connection between human rights, gender equality and the Environment with the aim to clarify the linkages and to contribute to improved policy and legal development. RWI has developed the following implementation strategies: Strategy 1: Strengthening KNOWLEDGE on the connections between human rights, gender equality and environment in the region, aiming to clarify context specific challenges and opportunities and to inform and influence policy, practice and discourse. Strategy 2: Strengthening multi-sector SYNERGIES, pursuing constructive collaboration and efficient inclusive and rights-based action towards SDG targets, building bridges and offering platforms for mutual exchange. Strategy 3: Promoting ACCOUNTABILITY in relation to programme topics for all in society, including for cross-border violations and actions of private actors, and adequate measures for marginalised and discriminated groups. Change is thought to happen when the three strategies each corresponding to one of the key problems, and contributing also to the programme at large, where each strategy builds and depends on and the results of others to the extent relevant and possible.

description.narrative:
2019 the RWI Regional project (RAPP) has contributed to the following results.
RWI's RAPP has secured a recognised presence within established environment networks across the region, with the most obvious being in South East Asia and the Pacific. The inclusion of a HRBA in UN/stakeholder conferences and research cohorts has been well received and resulted in RWI being sourced by network stakeholders to share their research and participate in their conferences. An example of the RAPP contribution is through its regional research project on human rights and climate change disaster and population movements involving researchers from 10 countries. This work has been quickly identified as reliable, timely and a considered for inclusion in DRR and CCA networks. RWI's 2019 consultations in Bangladesh, Fiji and Vanuatu were well attended and have generated positive consideration of the HRBA, but also resulted in RWI being asked to be involved in practical application of the research in the Solomon Islands in partnership with the NDMO and a local university that is launching a climate change focused masters programme. Furthermore, the research consultations were picked up by regional and national media outlets, meaning the research has connected to a broader audience that acknowledges climate change and people's rights as important connection points.
Another positive outcome of the RAPP is through it being networking and connected with significant decision-makers. An example of this is RWI being invited by the Indonesian Ministry of Law and Human Rights (MoL&HR) to assist them to better conceptualise localising their human rights and SDG obligations. The MoL&HR has an existing tool that assesses their provincial capitals and institutions for their application of human rights obligations. There have been some concerns raised by civil society stakeholders on its scope, levels of participation and monitoring capacities. The ministry reached out to RWI's RAPP programme for support and RWI is in on-going development discussions with them, which have some very promising indications of impact. It is important to remember the Indonesian ministry holds a responsibility to 280 million Indonesians, indicating the RAPP is well positioned to effect real change for a large number of people.
These examples are supported by many other research outputs and network strengthening activities within the RAPP's ultimate goal of achieving a just and inclusive sustainable development for human rights, gender and the environment. When the results are combined, they represent a persuasive and reliable contribution to the discourse on the importance of human rights in environmental concerns and responses. Nurturing interest and compounding commitments to human rights in climate change and the environment remains a key approach of RWI's RAPP. The RAPP's research and discourse contributions have gain some grip within an emerging area of consideration in climate change and environment responses. RWI is strategically maintaining a presence and promoting dialogue with duty bears and key stakeholders to ensure the message sticks and human rights are an active consideration in their responses and decisions.
Results from RWI RAPP Program (2017-2021)
Over the past five years, activities under RWI's ongoing project has delivered positive results. RWI has established partnerships with several universities which has led to activities on strengthening human rights education and research across the Asia/Pacific region. RWI has also launched several reports focusing on the the interlinkages between human rights and environment/climate change i.e right to a healthy environment, and climate change and disaster risk reduction in Southeast Asia and the Pacific. RWI has organized training for journalists in Indonesia on human rights and environment/climate change. RWI has also provided support to the NHRIs strengthening their institutional capacities, and strengthening their role as actors for change for human rights implementation and promotion.
